awd_titl_txt: Non-Invasive Personalized Normative Messaging Intervention for the Reduction of Household Energy Consumption
awd_abstract_narration:
1705273 (Lee). Household fossil fuel consumption in the U.S. is responsible for approximately 22% of primary energy consumption and CO2 equivalent emissions. Consequently, it is an objective of this project to identify widely applicable intervention methods potentially capable of promoting environmentally responsible behaviors. The goal of this research is to advance understanding of how personalized normative comparison groups influence the effectiveness of normative feedback interventions through the development and validation of a non-invasive data mining-based behavior intervention framework, with field experiments conducted in homes in Holland, Michigan. Successful implementation of the research would significantly contribute to reducing harmful emissions from the built environment through the enhancement of pro-environmental feedback intervention design by providing a detailed first look into personalized normative feedback. 

Specific research objectives are: 1) to classify households into several meaningful groups sharing similar consumption patterns on the basis of hourly energy usage data, using non-invasive techniques; and 2) to generate and then empirically evaluate the effectiveness of personalized normative energy use feedback created with the use of readily available consumption data. The research is targeted to  provide an in-depth understanding of both the reliability of personalized normative messages, and how and where energy use behavior changes. Further, it seeks to discover long-term effects of personalized normative feedback on household energy consumption and identify the effect of descriptive norm reference groups on energy consumption norm adherence and energy use. All of these could contribute to residential energy use reduction by advancing the theories for normative energy feedback. The findings on how and where personalized normative messaging changes occupant behavior in both the short and long term have important implications for energy reporting, policy making, and meeting of state and national energy reduction goals. In addition, lessons learned on personalized normative messaging on energy use can be readily applied to other pro-environmental behaviors (e.g., water consumption). Particularly, the proposed non-intrusive personalized feedback messaging framework may be capable of wide-scale deployment in advanced utility networks.

por.por_cntn:
Residential energy consumption in the U.S. is responsible for about 22% of primary energy consumption and CO2 equivalent emissions. It is predicted that continued increase in the atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide caused by anthropogenic emissions will lead to significant changes in climate with serious consequences. Occupants have proven to control up to 50% of total energy spent in buildings. Nevertheless, residents? undesirable consumption behaviors still exist at homes and cause residential carbon emissions regardless of which at areas they live in. Therefore, it is imperative to develop and deploy scalable behavioral intervention methods for reducing residential energy consumption.

Normative messaging intervention has proven cost-effective at promoting occupants? energy saving behaviors at homes. Residents are provided with information about their energy consumption with the addition of information about the mean/median energy consumption of other residents. By comparing residents? energy consumption with others, this will cause them stay in line with the average consumption of others. In the norm-based messaging intervention, one potential pathway for enhancing residents? behavioral changes is to personalize normative comparison groups for each individual. In practice, a group of neighbors is the most common for normative comparison even though lifestyle is more significant to residential energy consumption than geographic proximity. Also, the provision of energy consumption of residents with similar lifestyle can help them understand when they use energy mostly and, in turn, create more opportunities to reduce residential energy consumption. However, the current practice for creating lifestyle-based normative feedback messages requires residents to participate in the data collection (e.g., survey or home energy audit). Thus, it is difficult to deploy more personalized normative messaging intervention for a large number of residents.

To hurdle the current limitation, we devised an energy-cyber-physical system (e-CPS) framework that integrates homes with advanced energy grid infrastructure. The widespread deployment of advanced energy metering technologies makes it possible to create residents? energy use profiles which represent how they behave at home. Also, with cloud computing systems, a large volume of energy use profiles can be stored and processed to categorize residents into several meaningful comparison groups based on similar lifestyles. Lastly, by integrating the e-CPS with utility billing systems, lifestyle-based normative feedback messages can be sent to a large volume of residents in a non-invasive and scalable manner.

The proposed e-CPS framework was tested in Holland, Michigan to see the effectiveness of lifestyle-based normative messaging intervention. The significant findings are fivefold. First, residents are grouped into more similar lifestyle groups when their behavioral patterns are represented at a low temporal resolution (i.e., night, morning, afternoon, and evening). However, this does not mean that energy use data should be collected using advanced energy meters at a six-hour interval. This is because different data granularity can be required for other energy saving purposes in the residential sector (e.g., daily peak reduction). Therefore, instead of using a low data sampling rate, it is necessary to collect highly granular energy use data from advanced energy meters and then change the data resolution to six-hour intervals for the enhanced normative messaging intervention. Second, a deep learning (DL)-based clustering algorithm enables the automatic extraction of optimal features from residents? energy use profiles, thereby causing the members of lifestyle groups more similar than machine learning (ML)-based clustering algorithms. However, given the DL algorithm?s high computational efforts, the use of cloud computing systems is inevitable in the enhanced normative intervention for a large population. Third, most residents change their lifestyles at least one time during a 12 month period. Particularly, these lifestyle changes are most frequent when the seasons change. This frequent switching of lifestyle groups during season changes may undermine people?s identification with those groups.  Fourth, residents are not familiar with lifestyle groups and, in turn, less likely to identify with those groups than with neighbor groups. However, having a chance to interact with other members of lifestyle groups can strengthen attachments to those groups. This implies that the use of online communication platforms could enhance residents? feeling of connection with lifestyle groups and thereby strengthen the effects of norm interventions using lifestyles as reference groups.  Fifth, the ongoing field experiment shows that lifestyle groups are as effective at promoting residents? energy saving behaviors at homes as neighbor groups. However, as residents keep receiving the lifestyle-based normative feedback messages for the last periods of the intervention, they may become more strongly attached to the groups. Consequently, the use of lifestyle groups for normative comparison could result in further energy saving. More importantly, considering the vast number of residents exposed to the enhanced messages, even a slight improvement in the intervention effectiveness can create very substantial impacts on national energy consumption and carbon emissions.
